facts.text: Suit No. 103 of 1954 instituted by appellants against four respondents on 13th September 1954 in District Munsif Court at Turaiyur under S. 87 of Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This suit  No. 103 of 1954  was instituted on the 13th September, 1954, under S. 87 of the, Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act  No. XIX of 1951   hereinafter called the Act , in the

facts.text: Properties involved are agricultural lands situated in Eragudi village, Musiri taluk, Tiruchirappalli district.

anchor.surface_text: The properties involved in the suit companysist of agricultural lands situated in Eragudi village, Musiri taluk, Tiruchirappalli district.

facts.text: Lands granted in Inam to ancestor of Ambalathadum Pachai Kandai Udayavar by Carnatic Rulers before British power in India.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants, the said lands had been granted in Inam to the ancestor of one Ambalathadum Pachai Kandai Udayavar by the Carnatic Rulers before the advent

facts.text: Grant burdened with obligation of performing certain services in a Matam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants averred that the properties companyered by the grant bad been granted in Inam to the original grantee burdened with the obligation of performing certain services

facts.text: Properties alienated over time, resulting in appellants becoming entitled to them.

anchor.surface_text: The said properties were alienated from time to time, and as a result of the last alienation, the appellants became entitled to them.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 3 appointed as trustees of Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple at Eragudi by Respondent No. 4 on 7th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 4 is the Deputy Commissioner, Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments, L9Sup. CI/66 9 Tiruchirappalli, and he has been impleaded because he has purported to appoint respondents

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 3 obtained certificate from Respondent 4 that properties belonged to the Temple and filed application under s.87 Act before Magistrate for possession.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 to 3 who have been appointed as trustees of the said temple by respondent No. 4, obtained a certificate from him that the properties in question belonged to the Temple

facts.text: Magistrate overruled appellants' title claim and directed delivery of possession to Respondents 1 to 3.

facts.text: Trial court (District Munsif) decreed appellants' suit on 14th February 1955, finding grant was personal Inam, not religious endowment, title proved, and prescription upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appellants suit was decreed on the 14th February, 1955. Respondents 1 to 3 preferred an appeal  No. 129 of 1955  in the Court of the Subordinate Judge

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 3 appealed to Subordinate Judge Tiruchirappalli in Appeal No. 129 of 1955, dismissed on March 29, 1957.

facts.text: Appellants claimed title by prescription upheld by trial and lower appellate courts.

anchor.surface_text: The alternative plea made by the appellants that they had acquired title to the properties by prescription, was also upheld by the trial Judge.

facts.text: Pachaikandaswamiar sold all properties and left village.

anchor.surface_text: Another witness, Chandrasekara lyer by name, whom the respondents examined, also admitted that Pachaikanda had sold away all his properties and had left the village.

issues.text: does this article [Art. 134-B] permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property

anchor.surface_text: Column 1 of Art. 134-B provides for suits brought, inter alia, by the manager of a Hindu religious or charitable endowment to recover possession of immovable property comprised in the endowment which has been transferred by a previous manager for a valuable consideration. The period prescribed for such suits is 12 years, and the time from which the period begins to run is the death, resignation or removal of the transferor. Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?

holdings.text: Article 134-B applies irrespective of the representations made by the previous manager as to whether the property belonged to the endowment or his private property; it requires proof that the property was comprised in the endowment, transferred by previous manager for valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Column 1 of Art. 134-B provides for suits brought, inter alia, by the manager of a Hindu religious or charitable endowment to recover possession of immovable property comprised in the endowment which has been transferred by a previous manager for a valuable consideration. The period prescribed for such suits is 12 years, and the time from which the period begins to run is the death, resignation or removal of the transferor. Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of Art. 134-B requires only three facts proved by successor; character of transferor's representations irrelevant; rejects distinction to avoid unauthorized transfers being treated differently.

holdings.text: The transfers under Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12 fall within Art. 134-B as properties belonged to temple, transferred by previous managers for valuable consideration.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings recorded by the High Court, it is clear that the properties belonged to the temple that they have been transferred by persons who must be deemed to be the previous managers of the temple and that they have been transferred for valuable consideration. The present suit has been brought against respondents 1 to 3 who are appointed trustees of the temple by respondent No. 4 and so, all the ingredients prescribed by the first column of Art. 134-B are satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court findings on endowment ownership and manager status; applies Art. 134-B requirements directly to facts.

holdings.text: The alienors (previous managers) had been removed from management more than 12 years before suit; limitation under Art. 134-B began running then, barring the trustees' recovery suit.

anchor.surface_text: This evidence appears to us to show that the alienors had been removed from management of the temple, and other persons have taken up the position as de facto managers, and this position has lasted for more than 25 years. If that be so, there is no escape from the conclusion that more than 12 years have elapsed since the date of the removal of the previous manager who transferred the properties in question and so, if a suit were brought by respondents 1 to 3 on the date when they were appointed trustees by respondent No. 4, it would be barred under Art. 134-B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of alienors leaving village 25+ years prior, ceasing pooja/management, others as de facto managers for 27 years, 1948 notice of no trustees supports inference of removal; applies Art. 134-B starting point.

holdings.text: Appellants' suit decreed in entirety; High Court decree set aside as to Exts. A-3, A-6, A-12; lower appellate court decree restored.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers covered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 134-B applies but limitation expired; appellants' title upheld via bar on recovery.

Holding that Art 134-B applies irrespective undercuts Article 144 premise as alternative only if Art 134-B inapplicable

The holding's application of Article 134-B irrespective of previous manager's representations undercuts the Vidya Varuthi Principle under which Article 134 was inapplicable pre-1929 amendment because the manager/head was not a trustee.

anchor.surface_text: Column 1 of Art. 134-B provides for suits brought, inter alia, by the manager of a Hindu religious or charitable endowment to recover possession of immovable property comprised in the endowment which has been transferred by a previous manager for a valuable consideration. The period prescribed for such suits is 12 years, and the time from which the period begins to run is the death, resignation or removal of the transferor. Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?
We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers companyered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate c
We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers companyered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate c
for the last 25 years or so, the management has been taken over by other persons who are acting as de facto managers of the temple. This evidence appe

anchor.surface_text: for the last 25 years or so, the management has been taken over by other persons who are acting as de facto managers of the temple. This evidence appe

edges.explanation: h3 holds alienors removed more than 12 years before suit barring recovery, addressing i10

anchor.surface_text: This evidence appears to us to show that the alienors had been removed from management of the temple, and other persons have taken up the position as de facto managers, and this position has lasted for more than 25 years. If that be so, there is no escape from the conclusion that more than 12 years have elapsed since the date of the removal of the previous manager who transferred the properties in question and so, if a suit were brought by respondents 1 to 3 on the date when they were appointed trustees by respondent No. 4, it would be barred under Art. 134-B.
We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers companyered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate c
